extendedIngredients.aisle: Nut butters, Jams, and Honey;Health Foods
extendedIngredients.name: honey
extendedIngredients.originalString: ⅔ cup honey (see note above for vegan)

extendedIngredients.name: lemon
extendedIngredients.originalString: 5.5 ounces crispy lemon cookies (can sub another flavor; I used Lucy's Lemon Goodness Cookies)
metaInformation: (can sub another flavor; I used Lucy's Lemon Goodness Cookies)

extendedIngredients.name: lemon zest
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 to 2 teaspoons lemon zest or ½ to 1 teaspoon pure lemon flavor/extract, optional

extendedIngredients.name: oats
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 cup quick or whole oats (certified gluten-free, if needed)

recipes.title: Iced Lemon Cookie Granola Bars (No Bake!)
recipes.instructions: Grease or line a 9x9-inch baking dish with parchment paper (a 9x13-inch is okay, too, but will produce thinner bars). Grease the flat bottom of a measuring cup.Place the cookies in a plastic bag, seal, and smash with a mallet or similar food item into coarse crumbs and small chunks. Add the cookies to a large bowl with the crispy cereal and oats, and stir to combine.Whisk the honey, lemon zest or extract (if using), vanilla, and salt together in a small saucepan and bring to a boil over medium-low heat. Insert a candy thermometer and let bubble (no stirring) until it reaches 250F. Immediately remove from the heat and stir in the coconut butter until smooth.Quickly scrape the coconut-honey mixture onto the dry ingredients and stir to thoroughly combine. Pour the mixture into your prepared dish, and using the greased measuring cup, firmly press it in until even. Let cool 30 minutes to 1 hour.Whisk the coconut butter, lemon juice and powdered sugar together in a small bowl until smooth. Add the turmeric, if using  it doesn't notably alter the flavor, so you can use an extra pinch if it isn't yellow enough for your liking.Cut the cooled bars as desired, into squares or skinny rectangles, and drizzle with the icing. If the icing firms up too quickly, heat it in the microwave for about 15 seconds and whisk.

steps.step: Grease or line a 9x9-inch baking dish with parchment paper (a 9x13-inch is okay, too, but will produce thinner bars). Grease the flat bottom of a measuring cup.
Place the cookies in a plastic bag, seal, and smash with a mallet or similar food item into coarse crumbs and small chunks.
Add the cookies to a large bowl with the crispy cereal and oats, and stir to combine.

Whisk the honey, lemon zest or extract (if using), vanilla, and salt together in a small saucepan and bring to a boil over medium-low heat. Insert a candy thermometer and let bubble (no stirring) until it reaches 250F. Immediately remove from the heat and stir in the coconut butter until smooth.Quickly scrape the coconut-honey mixture onto the dry ingredients and stir to thoroughly combine.
Pour the mixture into your prepared dish, and using the greased measuring cup, firmly press it in until even.
Whisk the coconut butter, lemon juice and powdered sugar together in a small bowl until smooth.
Add the turmeric, if using  it doesn't notably alter the flavor, so you can use an extra pinch if it isn't yellow enough for your liking.
Cut the cooled bars as desired, into squares or skinny rectangles, and drizzle with the icing. If the icing firms up too quickly, heat it in the microwave for about 15 seconds and whisk.
